Is that why you mentioned them? Or because there are always discounts, I'm wondering. Is that in certain areas and just more detail about the higher discounts and how it impacted you?

My comment is that when you mentioned 4 to 5% on the 14th week on a year-over-year basis in 3 to 4, I'm guessing you mean that's the actual 14th week. My guess is that in most quarters you're back-end loaded so that in the final week, whether that had been the 14th week, the 15th week, the 12th week or a 7-week quarter, you would have a disproportionately high amount of your revenue in that week. So I would imagine that you're actually hurting yourself a little bit by saying it's 4 to 5% if that's actually the way you're calculating it because by the very nature of it being the last week it is higher than it otherwise normally would have been.
So I'm wondering if it actually maybe didn't – the 14th week by itself maybe isn't that high. And that's just a comment just to throw out there.

And then finally the numbers, it was terrific that you gave those numbers specifically on the products, like the Nexus 7000 and the ASR 9000 and the growth rates and the run rates are terrific. But given that they are somewhat sort of next generation types of devices on your Catalyst 6500 and your 7600 router, do you have any sense as to what the combination of let's say your Nexus 7000 and CAT6K and your combination of the ASR 9000 and your 7600. How are those doing as a grouped category?
Okay, Ehud, that's an awful lot of questions. Far more than I let Rod get away with. So Frank, why don't you – I'm playing favorites – discounts and then the week, please.

So when we look at margins as we talked about in prior quarters, the factors that drive margin variability have to do with the volume, the mix, the costs and then also the price, which is discounting and rebates. So what I highlighted from a product perspective is really just looking at some of the major drivers, not to identify that it was a significant amount but just the main drivers in the quarter were discounts and rebates with benefits offsetting that was driven by the higher volume and cost savings. So nothing significantly unusual. It's just some of the drivers of that, that comes into play from the product side.

On the services side, primarily related to the mix between our Advisory Services, Technical Services and also the extra week does have an impact with higher costs there. So those are just some of the factors that we constantly look at, as John said before, that impact our margins. So nothing out of the ordinary.

In terms of mix on the products, we gave an unusual amount of detail, which we won't repeat in future calls once we have a – more growth because the start-ups are tremendously powerful here in terms of how quick acceptance occurs. This is about as good as you do with a next-generation product in a single category, but to do it across every product category from the 7000 Nexus to the 5000 to the 2000, from the ASR to the 9000 to the 5000 to the 1000, to be able to do it with UCS etcetera, it was across the board very rapid increases.

So the best way to arrive at the number that you asked is that if you have Switching growing at 40% and it's about 35% of our total products, total business, and you have Routing growing at 23% and it's about 16, 17% of our total business, you can kind of back into the numbers. But overall the numbers were very solid no matter how you get them, market share gains, normal transitions, good mix, etcetera. It doesn't get any better on product transitions than what's going on now is the answer I would come away with on that.
We want to watch our time. Frank, on the week.

I quickly wanted to come back because I want to make sure that there's a correction there on the extra week. The extra week does not necessarily mean that, that was the 14th week. I just wanted to clarify that.

Yes. So it was not the last week of any quarter. The last week of any quarter is very high in bookings and revenue shipments as you would expect. It wasn't the first week either. So I would model it in the middle. We had a lot of give and take. This is an art on the number, and you can do the math. You can come up with a number of 300, 400, 500, or 600. We believe the numbers that Frank shared are the most likely on that. Each of you can make your twist, but it is a, I would consider it a week in the middle and it's a tough number to anticipate. Because when I asked around the room how many people were here when they did this five years ago, other than myself, no one in the room had been through it before. So it's our best estimate. If you're a little bit more optimistic, you could adjust appropriately. If you're a little bit more pessimistic on one of those, you can adjust the others. It's probably right in the middle if I were guessing. Next question, please.
Thank you. Operator, next question, please.
Our next question comes from Nikos Theodosopoulos with UBS. Your line is open.

Yes. Thank you. My question is on the lead times. Can you talk about which products are currently the ones that you still want to bring the lead times down in the fourth quarter? And at the end of the fourth quarter once that's accomplished, would you expect your purchase commitments to start declining, or do you think there would still be reasons for it to grow? Thank you.

Okay. We're probably not going to go by individual product areas. It varies because one time it can be as simple as some IPM materials, the next time it's power switch and next time it's an ASICs one. I think in terms of starting to discuss individual lead time product areas, would probably just start down something I don't want to start during the conference call, but I want to try to answer your question.

We made progress in almost all areas last quarter and then again this quarter on lead times. There will always be two or three product areas that either we mis-forecast or there's a problem with one supplier. As long as it's two to three we're fine on that, but we do need to bring them down a little bit tighter in terms of total by another one to two weeks. And there are a couple product areas that are currently running at the high end of that in terms of the categories, but breaking it down individually on it I think would be probably something I don't want to start down the path on. So let me give you one more question, Nikos, in terms of asking so that I can answer one for you.

Okay. Well, I mean, maybe we can just stick on this topic. I mean, assuming you accomplish the lead time reduction, what do you think happens to purchase commitments? Because they've been going up quite rapidly. Should we see them start to grow with revenues or start declining post the July quarter? I'm just trying to understand.

Sure. Very fair question. What you're going to see is we think supply will be tight for the entire year, and we will assume that it will be tight. What I've asked Frank to do and Randy and Angel to do is to make whatever commitments we need to, to meet our customer delivery dates. So I'd expect us to continue to make commitments in terms of being sure we get the components in and stretching out over a period of time.

So I'm really asking us to model not just for the next quarter but looking out 2, 3, 4, or 5 quarters and take the issues of supply constraints out of our dynamics on it. It's a relatively inexpensive insurance policy to be doing that and I think the way that we're handling it is right. So I'd look for us to continue to make commitments throughout the year, and I think that's required candidly that we think the supply agenda will be tight throughout the entire calendar year and maybe well into next year.
Okay. Thank you.
Operator, we're going to try to take 1 to 2 more quick questions, please. We recognize the time constraints.
Okay. Our next question comes from Brian White with Ticonderoga. Your line is open.
Good afternoon, great quarter.
Thank you, Brian.

John, when you, you talked a little bit about the order trends by enterprise and service provider. But could you talk a little bit about some of your discussions when you travel around the world, you talk to enterprise customers, you talk to service provider customers. What are the trends there? And what are the important topics on their mind right now?

Almost without exception, in this – what a difference a year a makes. A year ago I think we were one of the 2 optimists in Davos, or a year and a half ago and I couldn't find the other one. And when you talked to the business leaders, it was – the majority of them were very concerned.

I'd say now almost without exception, most people are beginning to slowly turn cautiously optimistic. They're very hesitant about adding head count, especially in the U.S. However, almost all of them have squeezed their expense levels down, have tightened things, probably cutting into muscle at times. And so they're looking as they want to grow new revenues, move into new markets by driving productivity and technology.

It's a nice way of saying that I think you're going to see the optimism in the technology industry continue throughout the next year, and that most of our customers we talk to are now getting very much involved with how they drive productivity, how they move into new markets ,etcetera, as opposed to focused on cutting expenses. I guess the best example was in our partner community, the 1,800, I took that survey up in front of everybody else, represents every country in the world imaginable, every size account, etcetera. And they were 98 or 99% very optimistic about the second half of the calendar year in terms of the questions asked.

I was in India just a short time ago, uniform across the board, they feel very good about growth in the 8 to 10%. It was just a short time ago people were worried about China not growing as well. And all of a sudden we're worried about them growing too fast. Barring a surprise, the Chinese leadership are very good. They'll manage through that as well.

So I think what you see is optimism building on a global basis. It won't be as big a bounce back as you normally see off of this deep of an economic downturn, which would normally be probably 7 to 9% growth in GDP. In fact, most people are a lot more optimistic than just a year ago. And I have very few pessimist customers at this time, almost regardless of country. I think everybody's a little bit gun shy, not wanting to stick their neck out or careful when they see a concern that it might have a domino effect. But right now it's dramatic change in terms of what we're seeing from almost every customer in the world.
Next question, please?
Thank you, Brian.
Our next question comes from Paul Silverstein with Credit Suisse.
I'm hoping I'm the last so I could ask 5 questions.
That was one and I might even try – I might try to squeeze in one more. Quickly, Paul.

All right. So John, I know you kind of touched on it but if you could give us some more insight on linearity, just a clarification. From what you said, I trust components do not impact EPS during the quarter?
Components did not impact – have an impact on UCS, no.
On EPS.

Oh, earnings per share. Did we make some of the shipments we could have made in the quarter because of long lead times? Absolutely. We didn't make some of the shipments. And in 2 tier and small business the products were either on the shelf or not. Was it a major impact in the quarter? No. Did it have some impact in the quarter in terms of either getting orders that could have shipped in this quarter, could have been on earlier lead times into the quarter? It had some impact from that perspective.
First part of the question, Paul?
Linearity?

Linearity. Again, it's hard when you take that 5% out. I mean the extra week out. If you move the week out of the middle of the quarter, linearity was relatively versus what we'd expect, it was clearly loaded more in the second month of the quarter since that's where we put the extra week versus normal times. But people, Rob, are back on forecast cash very accurate. Congratulations to you and your team. And they were pretty accurate the whole quarter. So I feel much better about having a good feel for where our business is and the momentum. And again, it was remarkably well balanced with almost all geographies except maybe Japan and Italy, Spain, Portugal, all geographies doing pretty well.

John, just to be clear, putting aside the extra week, if we looked at your last 4 weeks of the quarter, just from a sequential standpoint, is it what you would have expected in terms of ongoing strength?
Frank?
I would say it was.
It isn't 4 weeks, it's 5 weeks. The last month of the quarter is always 5 weeks in terms of the direction on it.
Okay. But there was no attenuation as you went through the quarter?
There was no acceleration in terms of the value into the quarter, no.
Actually, I asked the opposite question, John, which was there was no incremental weakness?
No. As the forecast held for the quarter, again...
There was nothing – let me just answer it this way: there was nothing unusual from that perspective in the quarter.
Yeah.

It was a good quarter from the standpoint of the continuation of business throughout, and then also how we performed. We actually, from a lead time perspective, we actually improved throughout the quarter as I mentioned earlier. So we did see improvement as the quarter went on. And we expect that to continue as we move into Q4.
Thank you.
Thank you, last question, operator.
Paul, did we get it answered okay?
Yes. Thank you.
Last question, please?
Next question comes from Jason Ader with William Blair.
Thank you very much.
Hi, Jason.

Hi. Historical seasonality has been up 5 to 6% in your Q4. I think I got that right. Now you're guiding 3 to 5% for this fourth quarter. So does this imply there was catch-up spending in Q3 which makes the comparison a bit tougher, and therefore you're guiding a little bit lower than in historical seasonality?

I think you're reading too much into that. We are very, very comfortable with Q4. And this is why I really – we made the statement beginning 3 quarters ago. We strongly encourage you to go back to year-over-year numbers because the quarterly numbers can vary by a big deals. They can vary by shipments, etcetera. This is why we said, beginning two conference calls ago, we would be switching back to year-over-year being the numbers, we strongly encourage you to focus in on.

You can tell just by the questions on what did the extra week bring you or not bring you in this, the effect of TANDBERG in or not and so I would strongly encourage our shareholders to look at the year-over-year growth numbers as being the proper indicator, to really watch the run rates on. And as lead times come back tighter, customers won't be ordering as far out, so you will see a natural contraction in terms of the bookings that go with that. And repeating the same theme, Q4 of last year was the tipping point on the upside, and you had a very good booking sequential quarter that we're comparing it against in terms of numbers for the next time period.

So what – one way to look at it then maybe would be if you guided 3 to 5% and you're able to show some exceeding of those expectations, it could be up sort of normal historical seasonality if you're able to exceed that 3 to 5%?

I think you're reading in too much for an extra point. The number I really think we ought to focus on, I'm going to be focusing on myself, this is how I run the business, is what's the year-over-year number? The year-over-year number is amazingly strong. It is almost – well, it is – it's 10 points higher than what we project our long-term growth to be off of not an easy comparable from a year ago. Our easy comparables were Q3, Q2, Q1. Now we're getting into the comparables that had good sequential growth and good numbers, and yet we're forecasting growth, even taking out TANDBERG, at a very high level.

So my own point of view, I would not add in a lot of plus or minus, a point or 2 sequential growth being a major single. It is absolutely the reverse of that. Watch year-over-year numbers. That's where the real trends are. I don't think there's anybody in this group that wouldn't be extremely excited if we, over the next 3 to 5 years are at the high end of the 12 to 17% range. And yet we're talking almost 10 points above the midpoint there. So that's what I'd encourage you to focus on. If I'm missing something here, come back at us over time through Laura or myself. We want to listen.

But the key signal is the market is extremely strong. We see very good trends. We're doing well in almost every product area, every geography, every customer segment. The innovation engine is on fire. We are transitioning from product line to product line, at a smoother pace when you're only doing one of these. Yet we're doing a dozen of them at the same time, and yet almost all of them are hitting, and still getting reasonably good balance even in areas like we addressed with Advanced Technologies which is a fair question, did you take your eye off the ball a little bit on that? Maybe, but it was 18% growth. That is unbelievably solid.

Our views haven't changed. We do not have a problem with growth opportunities. It's about execution. Our long term vision and strategy is playing out exactly as we expected. Our game plan for economic downturns is right on the money and hitting on all cylinders and we're gaining market share in every product area. I don't think it gets much better than that. Again, I want to thank everybody for joining us today. I appreciate the healthy give and take and look forward to some of the follow-up conversations. Laura?

Thank you, John. I'd like to remind everyone that Cisco's next quarterly conference call, which will reflect our fourth quarter fiscal 2010 results, will be held on Wednesday, August 11 of 2010 at 1:30 PM Pacific time, 4:30 PM Eastern time.

Please be reminded in light of regulation FD, Cisco plans to retain its long standing policy to not comment on financial guidance during the quarter unless done through an explicit public disclosure. Please call the Investor Relations team with any follow-up questions from this call.
We thank you for your participation and ongoing support. This concludes our conference call. Thank you.
